Mediterranean Ecologies in French-speaking Literature and Media 
In La Désirante, Malika Mokeddem writes: "Sur cette Méditerranée, j'apprends le sens de la disparition. Mes traversées sont celles d'un Ulysse sans Ithaque. Ulysse, quand les cris de milliers de naufragés remplacent le chant des sirènes" (155). In comparing Odysseus' itinerary to her female character in exile, Mokeddem pictures the Mediterranean sea as a space of erasure and disappearance in a context marked by North African and Sub-Saharan migration. What is the Mediterranean today ? What can Mediterranean ecologies tell us, regarding our context of ecological and migratory crises ?
In this class, students will examine the different roles of Mediterranean ecologies in three French-speaking areas around the Mediterranean Sea: Morocco, Algeria, and Southern France. But more than focusing on national borders, students will focus on Mediterranean landscapes, like the sea or the desert, to investigate how these ecosystems challenge the idea of borders. 
With discussions encompassing genders, migrations, environmental and social justice, students will think critically about ecosystems in Mediterranean literary and cultural productions.


A selection of texts, photographs, films and documentaries will help us to adopt pluri-disciplinary visions of the environment. This class will also engage with the work of NGOs advocating for environmental justice in the region.
